reviewText:
Fast paced, hard and addictive like any shoot'em up should be, but with an welcome fantasy theme over the usual space-battle-sci-fi-furutistic-neon.
There are six diferent playable phoenix, each with an unique ability to help you in the battle againts the sea of bullets the bosses are going to send your way.

Great addictive and fast gameplay, nice visuals and powerfull soundtrack are certain to give you a good dose of chalange and an overdose of fun.
voteText: 19 of 24 people (79%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I saw and I have played many Bullet Hell games. Some of them were harder or easier to get into but in my opinion, Phoenix Force is a great way to start your journey with this kind of games.\nStarts very easy - with one enemy which you can learn about, then starts to add more of them with even more different and more complicated attacks. Some of the combinations are deadly and demand from player to avoid them cleverly and that's where most fun thing starts. Every phoenix in this game comes with up unique skill so that every player can find a one that will fit in his play style to beat every level. There are 200 levels in total (100 in normal game + 100 in challenge mode) but these are really short and easy to beat once you will get a grip of everything.\nIt's not a hardcore Bullet Hell game like Touhou, but it's a definitely worth to play if you want something easier from this genre.
voteText: 17 of 22 people (77%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Phoenix Force is not worth $8.
It is a boss battle style shoot 'em up. The different birds you unlock have different special abilities,  the bosses are varied and interesting. It's not bad game, it would be amazing for a free flash game or $1 mobile game. The game is fun at first, but the further I got into it the more it started to wear out it's welcome and become very tedious - some levels would be a breeze while some had me pulling my hair out. In some levels you battle multiple bosses which is cool but also kind of seems like padding - but some combinations are very frustrating and make me wonder how much they play tested this game. In a good bullet hell game you die because you messed up, by throwing to random bosses together this game put you in situations you can't anticipate or escape from so it just becomes a game of spray and pray.

The devs are being rather greedy - if you can get this game cheap go for it, it's fun and will keep you entertained for a while.

reviewText:
This is Basic Shoot 'm Up Game.

Game is about dodging bullets and try to defeat the boss of every stage.
One hit you die ... no extra lifes... oldschool hardcore style..... !!!!
Shooting is beeing totally automatic and also the super power.
Super power will comes in handy if you can use it when you want and need it.
So most of the time is a waste of power because it shoots the wrong way or wrong time.

You play thought 100 stages and try to rescue all you bird friends.
They all have special touch like ice, fire.... or have faster shooting.
For me they all feel like the same so using another character feels pointless.

Personally I really like these kind of games.
Game has a cartoony way it's made and very funny.
Only this game is little bit disappointing.
It's more of the same and gets really boring after some time.
What really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off is that every level it's getting much harder only the rewards stays the same.
You need the reward for going lvl up.. so the problem is.
Rewards stays the same... LVL up goes very slow after 20 stages.
Only you get much harder bosses.. This is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t !!
So you need to farm points to make the game lititle bit easier.

Game is fun for a few hours ... very disappointing I give it a 6/10.

reviewText: Want to fight the same bosses over and over? This is the game for you! Nearly every level is a previous boss with one or two slight changes and maybe a second previous boss thrown in as well. You can level up your Phoenix, and unlock new ones, but there isn't any feeling of worthwhile progression. I wouldn't recommend this game.\n\nDesign wise the game is based on a converted version of their previous free flash game. If you use a controller, moving between maps has the trigger indicators reversed (ex: left trigger does what it says right trigger will do). The game has about ten minutes worth of music, it's nice at first but loops quickly. I didn't experience any crashes and the achievements seem to work fine, despite being a grind to get.
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is what I was lacking recently in shmup games. All the games in store are ok, but they don't have something special like this game does. A good setting, nice graphics, smooth music and upgrades, that make you complete stages over and over again to level up your phoenix. Neat! The game is not that challenging. It was ultra easy up to the stage where 3 bosses fought me at once. Yeah, sometimes it seems too grindy, sometimes - too easy. The thing I like the most - the bullets are not all those regular spheres, as it used to be in most bullet hell games. Every enemy has it's own projectiles (Harpy uses feathers, Gargoyl - chains, etc.) If you're a fan of bullet hell - this can be a great addition to your collection.\nCheers!

reviewText:
4/10, An iOS SHMUP ported to steam and it shows.  For what it is, it's okay.

GOOD

The second I saw Phoenix Force's artstyle I was in love.  It's a very smooth looking and neat artstyle.  All of the bosses are fairly unique looking and each one has its own attack pattern.  There are 200 levels which seem pretty significant at first but each level is only at most 30 seconds long.  Meaning you could play in bite sized intervals or go through every level fairly quickly.

BAD

Despite the great artstyle one extremely glaring flaw shows in it.  There are a lot of recoloured bosses.  Each one that gets recoloured has a slightly different attack pattern which might only catch you off guard once.  This game also has a... different view on what is difficult.  Instead of a single boss with a distinctive pattern, the game instead throws more than one boss at you.  It's difficult but a cheap way to raise difficulty.  With later levels having four bosses at once.  Since they do this many levels consist of fighting one boss, then that boss paired with another, then another boss.  I'm not expecting 100 unique bosses for every level but it feels kind of lazy padding.  Characters have little distinction between each other and it's likely you'll just be using the very first one just because he has the strongest bullet.  A little more interactivity would have been great, such as starting with the ability on cooldown and clicking when you want to use it.  Even if it had a longer cooldown.

reviewText:
This is a hard recommendation for me.  On the positive it is a clever game with a few good ideas, such as the incorporation of RPG elements and focusing the game on boss fights.  However, the game is hampered by a few issues that put it a step behind other, better, shoot-'em-ups like Crimzon Clover.

The first is the fact that there is no slowdown button.  There is no control button to slow your phoenix down to navigate the more complex fields of bullets.  Instead, the analog stick is pressure sensitive.  So, when you're using the lighter touch on the analog stick you're sacrificing maneuverability for movement safety, hoping you can maintain control.

A second big problem is the way the game is structured.  Since you only have a single life per fight, if you get hit, you have to go through a continue screen that allows you to exit to the map or select another phoenix.  These menus are animated.  Overly-animated menus are actually a huge pet-peeve of mine because they add that 1 second that's just enough to be irritating between bouts.  On later fights where death is a regular risk, you will go through this a lot, especially due to the often imprecise controls.

Thirdly, there's the repetitive bosses.  You will fight the same bosses over and over, ad-nauseum, throughout the game.  As you move forward, many of these bosses with become harder.  Either their attack patterns will change, their bullets will move faster or start homing in on you, or you will see some combination thereof.  When the ideas for tough bosses run out, the game is padded out with fights against two bosses simultaneously, which is fine, but still repetitive.  After seeing the same skeleton boss over and over through the game it got pretty old.

Finally, and arguably the most important, is this is a very, very simple game.  Unlike a lot of the best shooters ever made, Phoenix Force does little in terms of gameplay.  You auto-fire during the fights, so your job basically becomes dodge the things".  The bosses all move the same way
date: waving left to right across the top of the screen
recommended: and while their attacks are varied
hoursPlayed: simply moving in a U-pattern following them and focusing attacks on them between their pattern cycles will win you just about every fight.  What I'm saying is
voteText: there is no really unique concept here.  There are a ton of bullet hell shooters on Steam now and given the quality of so many of them

votesHelpful: but in all of its simplicity and attempts to be a progressive experience rather than a flashy arcade game
votesTotal: it loses a lot of the fun factor so many other games in this genre have.  The reason people love games like Giga Wing
votesFunny: the Touhou shooters or the masterpiece that is Ikaruga is BECAUSE they are varied and challenging arcade-style experiences.  The lack of simple RPG elements does not make them lesser games

reviewText:
Vertical shooters are an interesting genre. They strip away any notion of exploration and (often) narrative to instead focus on delivering high speed action to the player.
Phoenix Force goes a step further and gets rid of everything except the boss battles.

There's only an implied story in this, as a Phoenix you travel the world (like, Earth) continent by continent, fighting your way through 100 boss fights. For your troubles each victory gives you some upgrade tokens (proportional to the number of bosses were in the fight), some stages also give you direct stat boosts for your team or, most importantly, add a playable phoenix to the titular force.

Every phoenix controls roughly the same, you move your mythological bird around using the mouse (move it too fast and it will lag behind the cursor a bit) and automatically fires up at the boss or bosses that swerve around at the top of the screen. Once you get hit by a shot from a boss you're dead and immediately thrown back to the phoenix selection screen to try again. Losing is painless, quick and expected along your journey. Each phoenix has a neat special power to differentiate it though, from a fire wave that triggers every dozen or so seconds to bullets homing in on your enemies to being able to teleport around the map (with a short cooldown).
These powers do a nice job mixing up the gameplay, and I felt myself switching phoenix every now and then to chance my approach to a level.

The earlier mentioned upgrade tokens are used to increase the level of your phoenixes. Fortunately, they all level at the same time, which means that if you've levelled up your standard fire phoenix to level 9 and then get the ice phoenix it will also be level 9. All of them are always the same level, meaning you are always free to try a different approach or strategy. This is a great thing.

Unfortunately, you don't really NEED to switch things up though. As with Japanese Danmaku (or 'Bullet Hell') games the primary concern lies in staying alive long enough to take down the boss. This means that mostly you'll just be swerving out of harm's way as the bosses shower you with projectiles of various types. The different phoenix powers mix things up, but not to a great extent.

Levelling up a phoenix in your team (and, with it, the entire team) will raise its attack power and lower the cooldown period between skill uses if it has any. It's a completely linear and straightforward system, but it does mean that you can redo levels to get a bit stronger before tackling a level you're stuck at. Unfortunately failing a level does not get you a reward, which means it can be frustrating to try and fail a level a dozen times, it would have been neat to have at least something for the player's troubles. A victory gives 5-20 upgrade tokens, so just getting 1 token every time you lose would have been a pleasant gesture.

About halfway through the game (just after winning your first battle against 4 bosses at the same time) you unlock Challenge Mode, which pits you against 4 random bosses you've beaten so far. This is the only extra mode the game has to offer, and I'm glad it's there, but it can be frustrating as well. You get upgrade tokens normally for each victory, but the main prize to aim for is the final phoenix, Lich, which is unlocked when you win 100 challenge fights. This is exactly as many levels as the campaign has. I made it through, but was thoroughly sick of them when I did.
The final phoenix definitely mixes things up though, and is arguably a lot harder to play as than the other 5. Its shots start off very weak, but gain strength every time you graze  (almost get hit by) a projectile. This was great fun, but it's unlocked so late that I was almost done with the campaign by then and I didn't end up using it much.

After 100 campaign boss fights the game ends. You get a short slideshow of the phoenixes congregating around a magical tree of some kind (which, if the map you've been traversing is any indication, is apparently in Portugal). Did the evil boss monsters come from there? I don't know, maybe. There's no story here either to make things clearer.

There is one thing I haven't touched upon yet in this review, and that's the actual bosses. 100 boss fights sound ridiculous on paper, no game has 100 bosses, and this game is no different. Each continent (of which there are 4 in the game, I guess Australia and Africa don't have giant monsters floating over them? Good for them!) has four or so different types of boss that it introduces. Each boss has distinctly different attack types, which range from easy to dodge (fire breathing dragons, giant floating eyeballs shooting straight-lined lasers) to downright nefarious (harpies showering the screen with falling feathers, flying demons that alternate spewing out acid pools and smoke screens) as you traverse the continents. Design and variety of the bosses is pretty good, with every manner of flying mythological beastie being thrown your way as the game progresses.
Each new boss type gets introduced in a one on one stage so you can get familiar with its attacks, but the rest are generally made up of different teams of bosses attempting to take you down. No level is quite the same, but some of them are pretty similar.

Phoenix Force sets out to do a simple thing, deliver excellent vertical shooter boss battles with minimal surrounding hassle.
It achieves this, but could have done with some more variety in its battles and maybe some of that hassle after all (e.g. a deeper upgrade system).
Definitely recommending this though, make up your own mind if it's a game for you.

reviewText:
Phoenix Force is the tenth game I have played through completely, and the fourth that I got all achievements in. It's a very, very challenging game, and I absolutely recommend it.

As for the story, a group of phoenixes is tasked with defeating hordes of enemies, before they can reach a dying tree to revive it. 100 Levels, and 100 Extra Challenges (to unlock the 6th and last phoenix) offer hours of challenging bullet dodging and thinking of which phoenix to pick.

Fury, the starter phoenix, is able to elimite bullets directly in front of him, Cryo will freeze all enemies for a couple of seconds, Tupa is able to teleport around on the field, Gaia simply has homing shots (which will always attack the nearest enemy), Gast is able to summon a shield, and Lich gains orbs shooting along with it the more health it drains from the enemies.

And with this force, you should be able to clear all the levels - but be prepared to get frustrated at some of the more tricky enemy types!

reviewText:
First off. If you read my blog (all three of you) you're sure to see this exact but not quite review for the Desura version. I'm allowed to be lazy once in awhile...right?

Another 2D shooter, I'm guessing this was also a cell-phone port. The Phoenix Force travels the globe looking for minions of evil, and then blows them away. It's an adequate time-waster, something you can play for a few minutes and still make some progress. This game is 100 stages of boss-fights. Now that doesn't mean there are 100 bosses. There are several types, and each stage can have up to four of them on the battlefield.

The Phoenix Force consists of five different phoenixes. Auto-fire is constantly on and they regularly trigger their special ability (if they have one). Basically all you're doing is dodging bullets. Fans of scoring systems or even just points in general are left out in the cold. No matter how many enemy bullets you rub up against, or how close you are to the boss when it's defeated, there are no bonus points of any kind. Merely surviving is enough to earn a gold star, or a power-up, or a speed-up. The only points earned are experience, which you can cash in for a stronger bird. I went with the ice-phoenix. He has a name but I don't care. All I care about is that his special ability can freeze bosses for a couple seconds and slow down their attacks. The shield phoenix is also very helpful. At a high enough level it pops out a shield every 12 seconds.

That's the extent of the game really, just a lot of boss-fights. Due to the bite-sized nature of the game I stuck with it. The act of dodging bullets will always remain compelling to me. Perhaps it's a side-effect of the hundreds of 2D shooters I've played over the years. Hundreds? Really?! I mean, it definitely feels like hundreds sometimes. When you've got your face plastered onto the screen making those life or death millimeter-movements, everything starts to blend together.

But that's not all Phoenix Force has to offer! About mid-way through you unlock the option to fight random battles, 100 more of them. I know what you're thinking: A hundred boss-fights!? That's 10 times 10!!!" Yep

reviewText:
Very repetitive.
Gameplay is simple even compared to your average free flash shmup you would find on Kongregate.
Essentially, on one stage you fight boss A, then stage 2 you fight boss B, S3 boss A and B together, S4, Boss A (but at a higher difficulty)... after about 20 levels you will have fought 4 or 5 bosses. No other enemies, no power ups. no weak points. Just dodging the same patterns again and again.

reviewText:
Well, what can I say, this is an oldschool no-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t bullet hell game like momma used to bake. You're in for 100 levels of straight dodging and shooting action, and on each level there are 1-4 bosses whom you must take all at once (no other enemies), while dodging each and every one of their attacks, that's right guys, one hit and it's all over and you have to do that level all over again.

If that's not enough, hurting a boss enough unlocks their second and third tier attacks, and downing a boss makes all the other still alive bosses nastier by pumping up their attacks slightly. So not only you're dodging like crazy, you want to shoot at the specific boss you think is the most pain in the butt and you really don't want to face last.

There are like a dozen bosses each with their very specific and distinct attacks, and of course it gets pretty frantic how they are combined with several out at once. On the other hand you get to unlock like five phoenixes with distinct specials as well, and to level them up. The game kindly allows you to improve them all at once and you can try any level with the phoenix you think is best for the job, so don't worry, you can't make wrong choices and gimp yourself. It's just you, the player, versus the bosses, good old-fashioned fun.

For bringing back old school fun and challenge, I give it 3 out of 4 phoenixes. Thumbs up!

reviewText:
This game remind me of Touhou (a Japanese shooter game).
The gameplay is the same, you dodge all the bullets, lasers, explosive, rocks, all the things that the enemies throws to you.
Your character automatically shoot the enemy.
The enemies keep getting offensive each time they are in low health. (more bulltes, lasers, etc.)
You're dead if you were hit.
Your phoenix will be upgraded each time you pass a level.
There are 6 types of beautiful phoenix you can play.

I love to play Touhou series and this game is touhou alike so I would really recommend people to buy and play this game.
It's addictive, hard and challenging.
Oh yeah the developer are active in the Community Hub. That's a big plus for this game

reviewText:
Has mouse control.  That alone makes this game not crap.

Not enough info?  Fine...

Phoenix Force is a bullet hell shooter with no trash mobs, only bosses.  The same handful of bosses appear in various combinations of one to four at a time, which can get a little repetitive.  Each boss gains new attacks as it takes damage, and when one falls the others attack faster, so you'll need to choose your kill order wisely.

You can choose from six phoenices to play as, though only the ice bird is any good.  The purple bird was especially disappointing given the requirement to unlock it.  That said, the developer has shown a willingness to listen to player feedback, so character balance could change.  The once weak earth bird, for instance, got a big buff shortly after the game was released on Steam.

I'd say this game is pretty good, despite the constant boss reuse.  It got me feeling pretty wired, which I think is a mark of good difficulty.  The mythological motif is also a nice departure from the usual spaceships.  Definitely worth a look.

reviewText: Each level is a bullet hell skirmish between you and 1+ bosses.  Visually the game isn't very appealing.  However I can say; there is a crisp color distinction between your phoenix and incoming bullets, which is important.  The progression of difficulty between levels is well paced.  Easy to pick up and play for short periods, but just as easy to trance out and play for a long time.  Retry any stage you've beaten, and with different phoenix variants once you've unlocked them.  Mechanically, I found the game to be simple yet enjoyable.  If you have the opportunity, try it.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: A Challenging game made more so by the mechanics that force a rigid gameplay. The inability to store a useful special, like shield for example, to use when you need it makes it hard to rely on anything other than personal skill. Also the constant firing can cause you to shoot an enemy you don't wish to injure just yet. This can make the 3 group and 4 group bosses much more difficult. Other than those issues the game plays fairly well. A lot of extra padding with the way challenge mode works but nothing too awful that its unbearable. A good pick for people who prefer hard games.

reviewText: Phoenix Force is a bit slow to start, and it doesn't feel challenging until North America (Level 21). Even then, it feels like a Boss Rush RPG, since you can go back to prior stages and grind for level-up points if your power level is too weak. I don't know if that's really the idea with shmups, but I'll give it a recommend because it has cute artwork, I like the semi-transparent player fire (Touhou influence?), and I guess it'd be fun on a mobile if I had one that would run it (though maybe only South America since handheld shmups are kinda awful to control). Can't get the hang of using Tupã's teleport, though, and I needed a friend to tell me that it was a teleport power in the first place (yay being thrown into the game without any kind of instructions to explain the autofire and autobomb).

reviewText:
Surprisingly fun game, where you fight 1 or more enemies each stage, kinda like bosses.
You unlock different Phoenix as you progress through the game, and each one have different shots and special attack (the special attack charges and shoots automatically during battle).
The game is pretty hard, but it is rewarding when you acomplish the level.
Controls are great, and it does has controller support that works 100% (I'm using Xbox 360 cont).

Great game, and I think Devs could have made it even better if they keep investing in the game.
Recommended!
